III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
Section
Description The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency’s program statement and to provide for
the continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On the evening of 6/15/25, a youth had an injury to their finger and
wanted to be seen by medical, but the facility was short staffed.
Investigation Administrator 1 was interviewed via telephone on 06/17/2025
and on 07/15/2025. She reported Youth A injured his finger while
playing soccer and was not provided medical care. She reported
Shift Leader failed to report the incident and did not provide Youth
A with medical care. She confirmed there was sufficient staff on
duty, however medical staff were not onsite. Administrator 1
reported shift leaders sometimes are required to cover other
duties as assigned or requested, so on the day in question Shift
Leader was responsible for preparing the food, but the agency
was not short staffed.
Administrator 2 was interviewed at the facility on 06/17/2025, in
collaboration with DHHS Specialist. Administrator 2 reported he
was off on the date of the incident. He said Youth A jammed his
finger while playing soccer. Administrator 2 reported they currently
have eight youths and their ratio is 8:1. There were two staff on
duty, Staff 1 and Staff 3 and Shift Leader. The medical staff were
not on-site; however, the facility has on-call medical assistants
that live five minutes from the facility. He said staff are trained to
verbally report incidents of youth injuries within 15 minutes, and if
medical staff are not onsite, they are to call on-call medical. Shift
Leader was informed of the incident, she failed to document and
to verbally report the incident and contact on-call medical. He is
unsure why Shift Leader did not follow policy as the agency was
not short staffed. Youth A was examined by the medical
coordinator on 06/16/2025, and his finger was x-rayed. The x-ray
results indicated no fracture. Youth A was provided with a splint
and pain medication. Administrator 2 reported Shift Leader has
been put on administrator leave pending the investigation.
2

Administrator 2 reported Youth A shares a bedroom with Youth B,
who is his biological brother.
Youth A was interviewed at the facility on 06/17/2025, in
collaboration with DHHS Specialist. Youth A does not speak
English, therefore Administrator 2 sat in on the interview and
translated. Youth A reported he was playing soccer when the ball
hit his hand, and he hurt his finger. He said Staff 1 and Staff 3
were present when he hurt his finger. Staff 1 called Shift Leader
and Shift Leader told Staff 1 there was no one in the medical
office. He said later in the evening he told Staff 3 that his finger
was hurting him, so she wrapped his finger. Youth A said the next
day, he was examined by the nurse and was provided with a splint
and pain medication.
Youth B was interviewed at the facility on 06/17/2025, in
collaboration with DHHS Specialist. Youth B confirmed Youth A is
his brother. Youth B reported Youth A told him he hurt his finger
playing soccer. Youth B could not recall if Shift Leader checked on
his brother after he hurt his finger. Youth B reported he feels safe
at the facility; he gets enough to eat and denied any concerns
regarding Shift Leader or any other staff.
Staff 1 was interviewed at the facility on 06/17/2025, in
collaboration with DHHS Specialist. Staff 1 reported on the
evening of 06/15/2025 he was outside with Youth A when he hurt
his finger playing soccer and the agency was not short staffed.
Staff 1 called Shift Leader to inform her that Youth A hurt his
finger. Shift Leader said she was busy and could not assist. He
said Staff 3 told him that the medical office was closed, so he
could not take Youth A to the medical office. Staff 1 reported the
facility protocol is to notify Shift Leader when a youth is injured
and the shift leader would take the youth to medical and complete
an incident report.
Medical Coordinator was interviewed at the facility on
06/17/2025, in collaboration with DHHS Specialist. Medical
Coordinator reported she examined Youth A’s finger on
06/16/2025. She provided splint, ice, and pain medication. Youth
A told Medical Coordinator that Shift Leader told him she could not
do anything about his finger because medical staff were not on
site when he hurt his finger. Medical Coordinator reported the
facility policy when a youth gets hurt is to contact supervisor,
contact on-call medical, and complete an incident report.
3

Supervisor was interviewed at the facility on 06/17/2025, in
collaboration with DHHS Specialist. Supervisor reported he was
not working on the day of the incident, but was the on call
supervisor. He denied receiving a telephone call or email
communication regarding the incident. He was informed of the
incident the following day. He said the facility policy regarding
incidents is to immediately contact supervisor and if supervisor is
not available contact director and complete an incident report.
Supervisor said an incident report was not completed by Shift
Leader.
Shift Leader was interviewed face to face on 06/25/2025, in
collaboration with DHHS Specialist. Shift Leader reported on
06/15/2025 she was preparing dinner when she heard on the
radio that Youth A hurt his finger playing soccer. She went outside
to provide assistance’s since the medical office was closed. She
said Youth A told her that his finger was swollen, but when she
looked at his hand it did not look swollen. She informed Youth A
that the medical office was closed, so she offered him ice,
however he didn’t seem to be in any pain and said he would go
the following day to the medical office. Shift Leader admitted that
she did not contact Supervisor or complete an incident report,
because she was busy preparing and packaging dinner, and
covering the phones. Shift Leader admitted the facility’s policy for
incident reporting is to notify supervisor or director immediately
and complete an incident report. Shift Leader further admitted not
contacting on-call medical. Shift Leader again said that Youth A
did not appear to be in any pain and did not seem to be too
concerned. Shift Leader offered Youth A ice, but he declined the
ice. Shift Leader did a walkthrough before bedtime and checked
on Youth A and Youth A did not report any pain or discomfort.
Staff 2 was interviewed via telephone on 06/26/2025, in
collaboration with DHHS Specialist. Staff 2 reported she was not
working on 06/15/2025, however she heard about the incident
from Staff 3. Staff 2 reported that it is the responsibility of the shift
leader to notify Supervisor and director when a youth is injured or
not feeling well.
Staff 3 was interviewed at the facility on 07/15/2025, in
collaboration with DHHS Specialist. Staff 3 recalled on the day of
the incident she was helping Shift Leader warm up the food for
dinner, and when she went back to the unit, she heard Youth A
hurt his hand playing soccer. Staff 1 called on the radio to say that
he was going to take Youth A to the medical office, Shift Leader
told Staff 1 the medical office was closed. Staff 3 said she is not
4

sure what Shift Leader told Staff 1, because Staff 1 was the one
dealing with the incident. Staff 3 said the facility’s policy is to notify
the Shift Leader and they notify supervisor, document the incident,
and contact on-call. Staff 3 could not recall if she wrapped Youth
A's hand.
Documents Reviewed:
• Incident report written by medical coordinator dated
06/17/2025. Youth A was seen for injury to left hand from
incident, no bruising noted.
• Facility incident report policy states: All incident report
notifications must be communicated via phone and email to
the Program Director or Assistant Program Director as
soon as awareness of the incident occurs. Facility
procedure that staff are trained on: Children Incident report
are documented thoroughly and submitted in a timely
manner, regardless of the time or day. If communication
occurs before submission, notify administration via phone
or group text that an incident occurred and that report is
being created. All incident reports must be reviewed by
supervisor and communicated to the program director and
assistant director within 15 minutes of the incident or
sooner.
• Facility ratio policy: Waking hours one on-duty staff for
every eight youth.
• Facility supervised care policy: Shift Leaders are always
present during outdoor activities, outings, and events to
ensure children are adequately supervised, report injuries,
and address areas that may need assistance.
• Shift Leader Job duties and responsibilities: May perform
other duties as assigned or requested to support the safety
and reunification of youth in care.
• Shift Leader disciplinary and training record:
➢ 05/16/2025- Inappropriate communication in a group
setting.
➢ 05/23/2025 failed to report incident to supervisor.
Shift Leader
➢ Shift Leader Training record for incident reporting
dated 05/28/2025.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance with the rule, based on
interviews with staff and documentation reviewed, there was
sufficient staff on duty.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
5

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142
Section Health services; policies and procedures.
Description (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and behavioral
health care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The youth was made to wait until the morning for medical care.
The staff member did not follow protocol regarding contacting on-
call medical or the supervisors.
Investigation Administrator 1 reported the medical staff were not on-site,
however the agency has on-call medical staff that should have
been contacted.
Administrator 2 He said staff are trained to verbally report
incidents of youth injuries within 15 minutes, and if medical staff
are not onsite, they are to call on-call medical. Shift Leader was
informed of the incident, she failed to document and to verbally
report the incident and contact on-call medical.
Youth A reported on 06/15/2025 he hurt his finger playing soccer,
Staff 1 was going to take him to the medical office, but the medical
office was closed. He said Staff 1 called Shift Leader and Shift
Leader said she was busy. Youth A reported Staff 3 wrapped his
finger before he went to bed, and the following day he was
examined by Medical Coordinator.
Medical Coordinator reported she examined Youth A the day
after he hurt his finger. She stated Youth A’s finger was ex-rayed,
he was provided with a splint, and pain medication. Medical
Coordinator reported the facility policy when a youth gets hurt is to
contact supervisor, contact on-call medical, and complete an
incident report.
Supervisor reported he was not working on the day of the
incident but was the on-call supervisor. He denied receiving a
telephone call or email communication regarding the incident. He
was informed of the incident the following day. He said the facility
policy regarding incidents is to immediately contact supervisor and
if supervisor is not available contact director and complete an
incident report. Supervisor said an incident report was not
completed by Shift Leader.
6

Staff 1 reported he notified Shift Leader that Youth A hurt his
finger, Shift Leader said she was busy and could not assist. He
said Staff 3 told him the medical office was closed, so he could not
take Youth A to the medical office. Staff 1 reported the facility
protocol is to notify Shift Leader when a youth is injured and the
shift leader will take the youth to medical and complete an incident
report.
Staff 2 reported that it is the responsibility of the shift leader to
notify Supervisor and director when a youth is injured or not
feeling well.
Staff 3 said the facility’s policy is to notify the Shift Leader and
they notify supervisor, document the incident, and contact on-call.
Staff 3 could not recall if she wrapped Youth A's hand.
Shift Leader admitted that Youth A hurt his finger, and she did not
notify supervisor and director and did not call the facility on-call
medical. Shift Leader reported she offered Youth A ice, but he
declined the ice. Shift Leader said Youth A did not appear to be in
any pain and did not seem to be too concerned. Shift Leader did a
walkthrough before bedtime and checked on Youth A and Youth A
did not report any pain or discomfort.
Documents Reviewed:
• Medical attention form completed by Medical Coordinator
dated 06/16/2025. Youth A was examined for injury to left
finger and was provided with over-the-counter pain
medication and a splint for his finger.
• Facility incident report policy states: All incident report
notifications must be communicated via phone and email to
the Program Director or Assistant Program Director as
soon as awareness of the incident occurs. Facility
procedure that staff are trained on: Children Incident report
are documented thoroughly and submitted in a timely
manner, regardless of the time or day. If communication
occurs before submission, notify administration via phone
or group text that an incident occurred and that report is
being created. All incident reports must be reviewed by
supervisor and communicated to the program director and
assistant director within 15 minutes of the incident or
sooner
• Facility Emergency Medical Services: In case of a medical
emergency, consult the provider to determine if the child
should be taken to a pediatric urgent care center. Local
EMS and hospitals provide emergency medical care.
7

Emergency SIRs are submitted (by RD) for emergencies,
significant injury, or death.
Analysis The facility is found in non-compliance with the rule, based on
interviews with staff and documentation reviewed, staff did not
contact the facility on-call medical nor complete an incident report
when the youth injured his finger while playing soccer.
TECHINCAL ASSISTANCE:
Technical assistance was offered regarding defining what
incidents need to be reported and documented, so staff have a
clear understanding regarding what incidents need to be reported.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4149 Residential Nutrition.
Section (1) A licensee shall provide a minimum of 3 nutritious edible meals
Description daily unless medically contraindicated and documented.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth were served undercooked chicken.
Investigation Administrator 1 reported there was an incident on 06/18/2025
regarding Youth C reporting that the chicken was undercooked.
She notified Cook, who went and checked the chicken. She said
Cook checks each piece of chicken before serving with a digital
thermometer to ensure chicken is cooked over 170 degrees. She
reviewed video footage and saw that each piece of chicken was
checked with a digital thermometer. Administrator 1 reported they
recently started serving bone in chicken and so that’s the reason
the youth thought the chicken was undercooked. Administrator 1
reported Youth C has been discharged from the program.
Administrator 1 said an incident report was not written, however
she sent an email notifying management of the concerns and
moving forward she implemented additional procedures regarding
cooking bone-in chicken, such as extending the cooking time of
bone in chicken, and slice the chicken to the bone in each piece to
ensure it is cooked.
Shift Leader reported she was informed by Staff 2 that there was
an incident where youths were served undercooked chicken. Shift
Leader did not provide the specific date when this occurred. Shift
Leader denied any other incident regarding undercooked food.
Staff 2 reported she was informed by Staff 3 that Youth C
complained about the bone in chicken being undercooked. Staff 2
denied being present but heard about the incident from Staff 3.
8

Staff 3 reported on 06/18/2025 Youth C reported the chicken was
undercooked. Staff 3 notified Administrator 1, who immediately
notified Cook. Staff 3 said Youth C was provided with an
alternative meal and the chicken was thrown away.
Cook was interviewed at the facility on 07/15/2025. Cook recalled
on 06/18/2025 being notified about Youth C reporting the chicken
was undercooked. Cook reported they recently started serving
bone in chicken instead of boneless chicken. He said before
serving, each piece of chicken is checked with a digital
thermometer to ensure it is over 170 degrees. The safe
temperature according to standard safety practice is 165 degrees
for chicken. He checked the chicken and saw that the bone was
red, but the chicken was not undercooked.
Youth C could not be interviewed due to being discharged from
the program and has been unified with their sponsor.
Youth D was interviewed at the facility on 07/15/2025. Youth D
denied any concerns regarding undercooked chicken. Youth D
reported there was an incident last month when Youth C said his
chicken was not cooked and Cook came and looked at the
chicken. Youth D expressed his only concern regarding food is
when they serve fish. Youth D said he does not like the texture of
fish.
Documents reviewed:
• Email sent to upper management by Administrator 1 dated
06/19/2025 stating on 06/18/2025 Staff 3 notified her of
chicken that looked undercooked. Immediately asked Staff
3 to remove the chicken and offered youth a second meal
option. Cook was contacted to check the chicken meal.
Administrator 1 reviewed video footage showing
temperature check with a digital thermometer for each
piece of chicken and hold to obtain temperature. Cook
reported each piece of chicken temperature checked over
170 degrees. The safe temperature according to standard
safety practice is 165 degrees for chicken.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance with the licensing rule, based
on interviews and documentation there is insufficient evidence that
the chicken was undercooked.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
9

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
